awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: The DREAM STEM Project: Enhancing Academics, Entrepreneurship, and STEM Career Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthen education and research. The project at North Carolina Central University seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines.  The goal of the project is to educate STEM students who are critical thinking problem solvers, knowledge creators, skilled innovators, and are entrepreneurial. The project will impact all STEM majors at the institution, but directly supports over 200 students annually as researchers, peer tutors, summer institute or conference participants.

The project has the objectives to: increase enrollment and retention in STEM degree programs; increase persistence and graduation rates in STEM degree programs; and produce highly-skilled STEM graduates who can create and innovate. Each objective is supported by a set of evidence-based strategies and activities, such as proactive advising and mentoring, active-learning and inquiry-based teaching strategies, identity as a scientist, and entrepreneurship in science education. The project expects to produce strong effects on students' motivation, self-efficacy, and commitment to STEM that will lead to higher academic and professional outcomes for the students. A research study will be conducted to investigate the effects of active-learning instructional approaches in STEM courses on student motivation for learning and their academic performance.  The project will be advised and evaluated for effectiveness by internal and external advisory boards and by a team of evaluators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
North Carolina Central University (NCCU) was awarded an Implementation Project Grant from the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) of the National Science Foundation (NSF) in 2018.  The project entitled “The DREAM STEM Project: Enhancing Academics, Entrepreneurship, and STEM Career Pathways”, aimed to produce STEM graduates who are critical thinking problem solvers, knowledge creators, skilled innovators, and economic stimulators. The overall goals of the project were: (a) to increase enrollment and retention in STEM degree programs; (b) to increase persistence and graduation rates in STEM degree programs; (c) to produce highly skilled STEM graduates who can create and innovate.

Intellectual Merit:

The DREAM STEM Project effectively matched appropriate research-based/evidence-based methods for project activities that leveraged the uniqueness of the institutional environment to overcome barriers and enhance opportunities for STEM student academic growth and professional development. The project was organized around the following components: Proactive Advising & Mentoring, Active-Learning and Inquiry-Based Teaching Strategies; Identity as a Scientist, and Entrepreneurship in Science Education. Student’s identity as a scientist was strengthened following a strong model framework that addressed factors influencing competence, performance, and recognition. The project strategically helped build students’ scientific and technical skills, including through mentored research experiences, and provided opportunities for the knowledge and skills to be applied to real-world problems The project also helped to develop a mindset in STEM students that is innovation focused and entrepreneurially aware.

DREAM STEM participants gained science mastery skills increasing their science performance and competence and subsequently their confidence and motivation to learn and identify with science. Typically, undergraduate research experiences are the mastery experiences being considered in research that has linked the confidence and motivation developed in learning and identifying with science to academic success and persistence in STEM. The project has revealed that mastery experiences in design and entrepreneurial thinking produce similar results, and moreover, stimulating entrepreneurial thinking creates awareness in individuals for recognizing and acting on opportunities that can lead to economic benefits which is encouraging for STEM students who come from economically disadvantaged backgrounds.

Persistence, the critical antecedent to graduation, was viewed through a framework that identified a complex interaction of institutional factors, peer environmental factors, and individual student experiences factors. In the DREAM STEM Project, we found persistence and graduation rates in STEM for participants were dramatically higher than for a statistically matched sample of non-participants from the general STEM population at the university. DREAM STEM participants were retained in the STEM major at a rate of 94% after the first year compared to 65% for the statistically matched comparison group of non-participants. Persistence rates to the third year in the STEM major for DREAM STEM participants was 78% compared to 28% for non-DREAM STEM participants. Four- and five-year graduation rates for DREAM STEM participants were 33% and 65% respectively; compared to 15% and 21% for non-DREAM STEM participants. Also significant was the finding that students associated with the DREAM STEM Project, were 8.0 times more likely to be retained in STEM after the first year and 5.7 times more likely to graduate with a STEM degree after six years than a statistically matched comparison group. In addition, DREAM STEM students who were female, who come from families with very low/low SES, and who are first-generation college students were retained, persisted, and graduated in STEM at substantially higher rates than comparable students who were not part of DREAM STEM.

Broader Impacts:

The DREAM STEM Project at NCCU, funded by NSF HBCU-UP, added resources to the institution to enable strategic programming and innovative activities to be implemented which led to increased student success in STEM. The DREAM STEM Project specifically targeted the low-producing mathematical and physical sciences degree programs at the university to increase productivity. The DREAM STEM Project supported around 25 first-time freshmen and continuing students per year in various project activities leading to a total of 75 unduplicated participants over the grant period.  During the grant period, forty-two (42) DREAM STEM participants completed STEM degrees with 4(10%) Biology/Biomedical Sciences, 4(10%) Chemistry, 1(2%) Environmental and Geospatial Science, 10(24%) Mathematics, 16(43%) Physics, 4(10%) Dual degree Physics/Engineering, and 1(2%) Pharmaceutical Science. The demographics of the DREAM STEM graduates were: 2(5%) Asian, 33(79%) African American, 3(7%) Hispanic, and 4(10%) White; 27(64%) male and 15(36%) female.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2024
Modified by: Caesar R Jackson
